Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Biomanufacturing: Gene expression-based standardization of stem cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Darling, Eric M.
Proposal Number: 1547819

Cell-based biomanufacturing is highly dependent on its starting material: the cell. Using poorly defined, mixed populations of cells will result in unsatisfactory outcomes, regardless of the downstream technologies. Purification or enrichment of high-value material, like adult stem cells, is necessary for a broad range of existing and future therapeutic strategies. By better controlling the composition of the source population of cells, the performance of regenerative therapies and products is hypothesized to be more reproducible, making biomanufacturing approaches more feasible than they are today. Current enrichment techniques, which depend on the existence of unique combinations of cell surface proteins, are limited by very low cell yields and significant susceptibility to donor variability. In this work, the investigators propose to develop and evaluate new procedures that enable the production of stem cell populations with consistent regenerative characteristics, independent of donor.

The overall goal of this proposal is to rapidly isolate primary, mesenchymal stem cells and enrich for subpopulations capable of regeneration using an innovative cell separation device in conjunction with gene expression-based enrichment. This project will be a collaboration among researchers at Brown University, Rhode Island Hospital, and Endocellutions, Inc. To achieve this goal, a live-cell molecular beacon will be designed that fluorescently identifies cells capable of adipogenic gene expression. Human fat tissue will be obtained using the Adi-Cellutions device, and cells within the solid/liquid fractions of the isolate will be examined for their regenerative characteristics following gene expression-based sorting. Two specific aims are included in this proposal: 1) Investigate how gene expression-based cell sorting parameters influence high-yield acquisition of adipogenic cells, and 2) Establish a set of processing parameters capable of generating consistent regenerative characteristics in isolated cell populations, independent of donor. Gene expression-based cell enrichment is a potential, paradigm-shifting technique, vastly expanding the potential targets researchers can investigate beyond current, cell surface marker approaches. More practically, the methodologies generated from this project will provide a roadmap for other investigators to obtain more consistent populations of cells for use in basic science experiments as well as clinical procedures. The proposed academic-industry collaboration will result in contributions to the fields of biomedical engineering, cell and molecular biology, and clinical medicine. Undergraduate, graduate, and medical students will participate throughout all stages of the proposed project, and experimental findings will be distributed through scientific communications and educational venues at Brown University and partnering hospitals.

Institution.Name: Brown University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BROWN UNIVERSITY IN PROVIDENCE IN THE STATE OF RHODE ISLAND AND PROVIDENCE PLANTATIONS

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research project was to determine ways to enrich for adult stem cells that have predictable therapeutic capabilities. Adult stem cells can be taken from fat tissue, and if given the right chemical signals, they will change into bone, fat, or other tissue-specific cell types. However, not all stem cells are the same, with some being better or worse at this “differentiation” process. There is interest in the medical community for using stem cells to heal tissues damaged by injury or disease, but the unpredictable nature of the cell mixtures makes it difficult to judge whether a given patient’s cells will result in success. When the cells are taken from the body, typically by liposuction, the result is a mixture. Some cells are capable of contributing to healing, while others are not and may even slow down healing. Our initial work focused on using gene expression-based markers to target cells, but limitations in the consistency of commercial materials required us to shift directions. We thus turned our attention to marker molecules on the surface of cells. We hypothesized that these could be used to determine which cells would be beneficial and result in at least a minimal positive response for a given purpose, like healing fat. Over the last three years, we have studied the variability in stem cell response for samples taken from over a dozen human donors and developed new techniques to help identify novel markers associated with fat-tissue repairing cells. As our work progressed, we created several methods to help us study and use mixed cell populations. We also rigorously evaluated the common cell sorting techniques in our field for their ability to enrich for stem cells in an efficient manner. All of the research completed as part of this project has been published and/or is available according to NSF guidelines.

We made appreciable progress towards our primary goal of understanding the variability of stem cell responses across human donors. Our main outcomes showed that a person’s past medical history is important to consider, with conditions like breast cancer having long-term effects on the differentiation and immune capabilities of fat-derived stem cells. Additionally, the cellular variation observed from patient-to-patient emphasizes the need to first enrich for function-specific cells before using them in a therapy. Towards this goal, we invented a biomarker discover process that first targets highly specific proteins in cells to sort them into sub-groups that could be examined for more accessible markers on their surface. These new markers can then be potentially used to isolate and enrich for cells with function-specific purposes. These methods will benefit not only the field of regenerative medicine but also many other biological fields that seek to understand what one cell type in a mixture of cells is doing.

In parallel with the work above, we conducted a rigorous evaluation of the major, existing cell sorting techniques: fluorescence-assisted cell sorting (FACS) and magnetic-assisted cell sorting (MACS). Both techniques rely on labeling cell surface markers to distinguish what a cell is or what it is capable of. FACS then sorts cells by flowing them past a light-based detector, whereas MACS uses magnets to pull labeled cells out of a larger mixture. We found that MACS performed better for characteristics that would be needed in clinical therapies, including short processing time, high cell throughputs, and excellent yields. FACS performed more poorly in these categories but had substantial advantages as a research tool due to signal resolution and multiple marker recognition.

From a broader impacts standpoint, this project involved a collaboration with the company EndoCellutions. Our goal was to evaluate the characteristics of cells residing in different compartments of the Lipo-Pro device and potentially enrich for a subset of them using novel biomarkers. While we were limited in the number and type of tests we could run, red blood cells were found to be the most dominant cell type in all regions of the device. Other cell types appeared to be relatively consistent across compartments and were hypothesized to be contributors to the fat engraftment healing response.


Last Modified: 09/07/2018
Modified by: Eric M Darling

Adult stem cells can be taken from fat tissue, and if given the right chemical signals, they will change into bone, fat, or other tissue-specific cell types. However, not all stem cells are the same, with some being better or worse at this "differentiation" process. There is interest in the medical community for using stem cells to heal tissues damaged by injury or disease, but the unpredictable nature of the cell mixtures makes it difficult to judge whether a given patient?s cells will result in success. When the cells are taken from the body, typically by liposuction, the result is a mixture. Some cells are capable of contributing to healing, while others are not and may even slow down healing. Our initial work focused on using gene expression-based markers to target cells, but limitations in the consistency of commercial materials required us to shift directions. All of the research completed as part of this project has been published and/or is available according to NSF guidelines.
